case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Raja Yadvendra Dutt Dube

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 123 of 1965 filed by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated November 28, 1963 in A.I.T. Reference No. 16 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 123 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated November 28, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in A.I.T. Reference No. 16 of 1960.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer, Jaunpur assessed Raja Yadvendra Dutt Dube (respondent) under S. 16(3) of U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948 on May 14, 1949 for 1355 Fasli (July 1, 1947 to June 30, 1948) on net income of Rs. 72,769/15/2.

anchor.surface_text: By order, dated May 14, 1949 the Sub-Divisional Officer, Jaunpur, assessed Raja Yadvendra Dutt Dube hereinafter called the respondent-under S. 16 3  of the U. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948 to pay agricultural income-tax for the account period 1355 Fasli  July 1, 1947 to June 30, 1948  on a net income of Rs. 72,769/15/2.

facts.text: Collector of Jaunpur recomputed tax under S. 25 read with S. 16(4) on June 9, 1950 for same period on total net income of Rs. 80,859/13/6 as income escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Being of the view that a part of the income of the respondent had escaped assessment, the Collector of Jaunpur by order, dated June 9, 1950, recomputed tax under S. 25 read with s. 16 4  of the Act for the said account period on a total net income of Rs. 80,859/13/6.

facts.text: Agricultural Income-tax Commissioner set aside orders of Collector and Sub-Divisional Officer on March 5, 1952 in respondent's appeal, directed Collector to reopen assessment for 1355 Fasli after notice.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by the respondent the Agricultural Income-tax Commissioner by order dated March 5, 1952, set aside the orders of the Collector and also of the Sub- Divisional Officer and directed that the assessment be reopened by the Collector and fresh assessment of the income for 1355 Fasli be made after giving notice to the respondent.

facts.text: Commissioner held Sub-Divisional Officer assessment without jurisdiction and Collector's reassessment invalid as substitution.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Commissioner, assessment made by the Sub-Divisional Officer was without jurisdiction, and the order of reassessment by the Collector being in review and substitution of the order of assessment, want of jurisdiction in the order of assessment attached to the order of reassessment as well.

facts.text: Board of Revision agreed Sub-Divisional Officer order illegal but held Commissioner exceeded authority, suo motu set aside Sub-Divisional Officer order and directed fresh assessment by Collector.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved the Board of Revision against the order of the Commissioner. The Board agreed with the Commissioner, that the assessment order made by the Sub-Divisional Officer was illegal and invalid, but in the view of the Board the Commissioner exceeded his authority in setting aside the order of the Sub-Divisional Officer, which was not challenged in appeal before him.

facts.text: Board of Revision on October 15, 1952 referred question to Allahabad High Court under S.24(4): Whether Board could direct fresh assessment under S.25.

anchor.surface_text: The Board then referred under s. 24 4  of the Act the following question of law to the High Court of Allahabad for opinion Whether on the facts and having regard to the provisions of section 25 of the Act, the Board could on the 15th October, 1952, direct a fresh assessment to be made ?

facts.text: Allahabad High Court answered the reference in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, recorded an answer in the negative. The State of Uttar Pradesh has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Uttar Pradesh has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Gross agricultural income of respondent exceeded Rs. 1 lakh as found by Sub-Divisional Officer.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground however that the respondent filed the return in pursuance of a notice under s. 15 3 , and that the Sub-Divisional Officer found in the course of the assessment proceeding that the gross agricultural income of the respondent exceeded Rs. 1 lakh.

facts.text: Respondent filed return in pursuance of notice under S.15(3) issued by Sub-Divisional Officer.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground however that the respondent filed the return in pursuance of a notice under s. 15 3 ,

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer lacked jurisdiction to assess as gross income exceeded Rs.1 lakh per S.14(2).

anchor.surface_text: The order of assessment passed by the Sub-Divisional Officer was set aside by the Board because the Sub-Divisional Officer had no jurisdiction to assess to tax income of a person whose gross agricultural income exceeded Rs. 1 lakh,

facts.text: Collector is assessing authority for cases where gross agricultural income exceeds Rs.1 lakh per S.14.

anchor.surface_text: In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub- section  1 , the following authorities shall be the assessing authorities in the cases mentioned against each namely Assistant Collector Incharge of sub- division. Where the gross agricultural income does not exceed Rs. 1 lakh. Collector In all cases.

facts.text: Notice under S.15(3) issued by Sub-Divisional Officer was unauthorised as he lacked jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The notice under S. 15 3  was issued to the respondent by the Sub-Divisional Officer, presumably on the assumption that the gross agricultural income of the respondent did not exceed Rs. 1 lakh but when the Sub-Divisional Officer found on scrutiny of the return that the gross agricultural income of the respondent exceeded Rs. 1 lakh, he could not exercise the powers of the assessing authority.

facts.text: Board of Revision quashed notice under S.15(3) by implication by setting aside assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Board of Revision did not expressly Set aside the notice issued by the Sub-Divisional Officer under S. 15  3 , but the Board agreed with the Commissioner that the original order of assessment passed by the Sub- Divisional Officer was absolutely without jurisdiction,

facts.text: Supreme Court held Board could not direct fresh assessment without fresh notice under S.15(3) or S.25 within time.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in the answer which it recorded.

facts.text: Notice under S.25 by Collector was quashed by Board direction for fresh proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector issued a notice under s. 25 for reassessing income which had escaped assessment and assessed the income of the respondent, but the proceeding of the Collector was set aside as unauthorised, and the Collector was directed to start a fresh proceeding for assessment.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: T. Desai and O. P. Rana.

anchor.surface_text: T. Desai and O. P. Rana, for the appellant.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent: V. Viswanatha Sastri, M. V. Goswami and B. C. Misra.

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri, M. V. Goswami and B. C. Misra, for the respondent.

facts.text: Account period 1355 Fasli corresponds to July 1, 1947 to June 30, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: for the account period 1355 Fasli  July 1, 1947 to June 30, 1948  on a net income of Rs. 72,769/15/2.

facts.text: High Court jurisdiction under S.24 is advisory, limited to question referred.

anchor.surface_text: Jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 24 is advisory the High Court must answer the question referred to it and cannot travel outside the terms of the reference.

arguments.claim: The Sub-Divisional Officer was invested with authority to issue a notice under S. 15(3) calling for a return, and since this notice was not set aside by the Commissioner or by the Board of Revision, the Collector can use it for fresh assessment without transgressing S. 15(3) or S. 25.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State raised three contentions in support of the plea that the Board had power to direct the Collector to make a fresh assessment The Sub-Divisional Officer was invested with authority to issue a notice under S. 15 3  calling for a return, and since this notice was not set aside by the Commissioner or by the Board of Revision,

arguments.court_reasoning: Notice was unauthorised as SDO lacked jurisdiction and was quashed implicitly by Board when setting aside assessment order.

arguments.claim: Without a fresh notice under S. 15(3), the Collector has power by virtue of notice under S. 15(1) to assess on the return made pursuant to the notice issued by the Sub-Divisional Officer.
arguments.court_reasoning: Proceedings based on invalid notice cannot be revived by general S.15(1) notice years later; entire proceedings vacated.

arguments.claim: Notice under S. 25 issued within time by Collector was valid, so assessment proceedings directed by Board can be founded on that notice.
arguments.court_reasoning: S.25 notice by Collector was set aside as unauthorised; Board directed fresh proceedings requiring new notice.

arguments.claim: By the expression 'without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub-section (1)' in S.14(2), power is conferred upon Assistant Collector (SDO) to assess income exceeding Rs. 1 lakh.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; SDO lacked jurisdiction per S.14(2).

arguments.claim: Assessing authority (SDO) has power to decide jurisdictional facts (gross income > Rs.1 lakh).

arguments.claim: Notice under S.15(3) issued by SDO unauthorised as lacked jurisdiction; quashed implicitly by Board.

anchor.surface_text: The notice under S. 15 3  was issued to the respondent by the Sub-Divisional Officer, presumably on the assumption that the gross agricultural income of the respondent did not exceed Rs. 1 lakh but when the Sub-Divisional Officer found on scrutiny of the return that the gross agricultural income of the respondent exceeded Rs. 1 lakh, he could not exercise the powers of the assessing authority.

arguments.claim: S.25 notice by Collector quashed by Board's direction for fresh proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector issued a notice under s. 25 for reassessing income which had escaped assessment and assessed the income of the respondent, but the proceeding of the Collector was set aside as unauthorised, and the Collector was directed to start a fresh proceeding for assessment.

arguments.claim: High Court jurisdiction under S.24 advisory, limited to referred question.

anchor.surface_text: Jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 24 is advisory the High Court must answer the question referred to it and cannot travel outside the terms of the reference.

holdings.text: Jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 24 is advisory; the High Court must answer the question referred to it and cannot travel outside the terms of the reference.

anchor.surface_text: Jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 24 is advisory the High Court must answer the question referred to it and cannot travel outside the terms of the reference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision limits High Court to advisory role on referred question under s.24.

holdings.text: The Court is only concerned with whether the Board had authority to direct re-assessment in light of s.15(3) and s.25.

anchor.surface_text: concerned to deal with the limited question whether the Board had authority on the view expressed by it to make the order directing re- assessment, and that question must be decided in the light of the provisions of s. 15 3  and S. 25 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limits scope due to advisory jurisdiction on reference.

holdings.text: Under s.14(2), the Collector alone is the assessing authority where gross agricultural income exceeds Rs.1 lakh.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment the Sub-Divisional Officer found that the total gross income of the respondent exceeded Rs. 1 lakh, and under s. 14 2  the Collector alone was the assessing authority in respect of the income of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.14(2) to facts where SDO found gross income exceeded limit.

holdings.text: Expression 'without prejudice to the generality of sub-s.(1)' in s.14(2) does not confer power on Assistant Collector to assess income exceeding Rs.1 lakh.

anchor.surface_text: The contention raised by counsel for the State that by the expression without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub-section  1  in sub-s.  2  of s. 14 power is intended to be conferred upon the Assistant Collector in charge of a sub-division to assess income of an assessee whose gross agricultural income exceeds Rs. 1 lakh cannot be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.14(1) and (2) together: Collector unlimited, SDO limited.

holdings.text: Assessing authority, as tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction, has power to decide jurisdictional facts subject to superior court rectification.

anchor.surface_text: but as in other taxing statutes where the taxing authority is constituted a tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction the authority has the power, subject to rectification by a superior Court, to decide facts on the proof of which his jurisdiction depends.

holdings.text: Sub-Divisional Officer had power to decide whether gross agricultural income exceeded Rs.1 lakh.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Officer had therefore power to decide whether the gross agricultural income of the respondent did or did not exceed Rs. 1 lakh

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from power to decide jurisdictional facts.

holdings.text: Notice under s.15(3) issued by Sub-Divisional Officer unauthorised once gross income found to exceed Rs.1 lakh.

anchor.surface_text: The notice under S. 15 3  was issued to the respondent by the Sub-Divisional Officer, presumably on the assumption that the gross agricultural income of the respondent did not exceed Rs. 1 lakh but when the Sub-Divisional Officer found on scrutiny of the return that the gross agricultural income of the respondent exceeded Rs. 1 lakh, he could not exercise the powers of the assessing authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: SDO ceases to be assessing authority upon finding jurisdictional fact.

holdings.text: No provision for transfer of proceedings from Sub-Divisional Officer to Collector upon finding lack of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Act or the Rules for transfer of proceeding from the Sub-Divisional Officer to the Collector, when the Sub-Divisional Officer in dealing with a return finds that he has no jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Proceedings including notice under s.15(3) by Sub-Divisional Officer unauthorised and void unless conclusion on jurisdiction set aside.

anchor.surface_text: When he arrived at the conclusion that the gross income of the respondent exceeded Rs. 1 lakh, the proceeding initiated by the Sub-Divisional Officer including the issue of notice must, unless that conclusion is set aside by a superior authority, be held unauthorised, for the power to issue a notice under s. 15  3  is only conferred upon the assessing authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power to issue notice limited to proper assessing authority per s.2(6).

holdings.text: Notice under s.15(3) issued by Sub-Divisional Officer quashed implicitly by Board of Revision.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Board set aside assessment for want of jurisdiction, implicitly quashing foundational notice; directed fresh notice.

holdings.text: Collector cannot assess relying on return to invalid s.15(3) notice using general s.15(1) notice years later.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid proceedings vacated entirely; general notice insufficient for delayed assessment without fresh s.15(3).

holdings.text: s.25 notice by Collector quashed by Board's direction for fresh proceedings with new notice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Board's order set aside prior s.25 proceedings, requiring fresh notice.

holdings.text: Board could not direct fresh assessment on October 15, 1952, as no valid notice under s.15(3) or s.25 available.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and having regard to the provisions of section 25 of the Act, the Board could on the 15th October, 1952, direct a fresh assessment to be made ? The High Court, recorded an answer in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior notices quashed implicitly; time limits under ss.15(3),25(3) expired; affirmed High Court.
